entry.title: Sakura-Con 2013 Cosplay: Black Rock Shooter Strength
entry.content:
(source)

For this year's Sakura-Con I cosplayed Strength as part of a Black Rock Shooter group! (I did start out as Demon Canon User…but let's face it, Strength is so much cooler.)

starting to place together the cardboard

I had a lot of help from Andou with the creation of the Ogre Arms, which were made with an impressive amount of cardboard, tape, and some industrial-strength glue.

suddenly realizing how huge this is gonna be

I also could barely lift them.

palm detail

After the hands were put together, our next problem was how to get the black paint on evenly.

amidst his masterpieces

The paint we had sank into test pieces of cardboard, but didn't stick to the tape bits. Luckily, we discovered an all-purpose primer at an Ace Hardware which a woman added a gray hue to for us, so that we could achieve the dark black we wanted.

primer time

It took a couple months to construct, and about a week to paint, and afterward Andou edged out the fingers with silver to give it a metallic look.

As for the dress…I had this idea that I would eyeball the entire thing, and this would just not work for the lovely back that this costume has. I ended up trying to eyeball the dress twice before resigning myself to crawling the Internet for patterns. Luckily, I found a really great tutorial on how to make a "racerback" tank top, and from there it was pretty easy! (Though still time-consuming.)

The collar was made out of a piece of foam, which we covered with black fabric and white felt and secured in the back with a plate of cardboard and some screws. (Andou's touch, which I think is awesome.)



The tail was the thing that got thrown under the bus this time, as the deadline neared: that was fashioned somewhat crudely from leftover foam covered in masking tape, painted over in black, and sewn to the back of my biking shorts. The tape slowly unraveled throughout Con, but luckily neither it (or the arms!) broke apart entirely, despite my panicking throughout the weekend.

Without further ado, here are photos from my group's photoshoot, all taken by the super-talented Jaymee Masui!

our whole group!


"group hug"


strength & gold saw, who i am told have a special relationship

More group photos can be seen at Kimidori Cosplay. This was my best cosplay yet, and part of what made it wonderful was the help of Andou with the props, Aubrey with the wig, and my awesome Merch Staff friends. Here's to many years ahead. ^___^

Fun fact: the arms were so heavy that I actually gained non-negligible muscle mass over the course of the weekend…haha. And I definitely returned to Real Life on Monday without the ability to raise my (very, very sore) arms over my head.

What's next? Well, recently I've been daydreaming about doing Red from Supergiant's upcoming Transistor...we'll see how that goes.

Comments

axcho
Haha, Andou looks so awesome there with his... *ahem* handiwork. ;)

And you look awesome too, of course! Great choice - I'm impressed at how you pulled it off. :)

entry.title: Okami Cosplay Pt. 2
entry.content:
It occurs to me that I never did update after my previous post on our Okami cosplay. Since then there have been some lovely photos by Jia-Ling Pan.

okami celestial brush gods: group photo!

By the time our tired merch staff had the time to finally be together, we were exhausted and it was past sunset, so we posed underneath some of the convention center lighting.

werq that lighting

I really appreciated Jia-Ling taking our photos...not only was she dedicated to making sure the lighting worked, but she also tried to get at the heart of our characters' personalities and making sure they showed through. Though, I have to admit that the Celetial Brush Gods don't really have too much personality in the games.

nuregami & moegami: water and fire!

And here's one (of the very few photos I personally took) of our Tachigami:

tachigami cosplay

I have no idea what I'm doing next year.

entry.title: Okami Cosplay
entry.content:
The roosterphoenix god of Okami is almost always seen indulging in some smoking pipe.  It's so characteristic that I knew I had to make for this year's planned cosplay.

moegami and pipe (source)

I'd never made a cosplay prop before, and had resigned myself to finding a thick dowel of some kind to paint, when I rounded an aisle and discovered...plastic candles.


behold, a plastic candle

They were perfect.  I purchased a pair of them.  They were so cheap that I could unscrew the individual components apart, after which I used a hot glue gun to attach two of the plastic candle bodies to each other.

plastic candle, dissembled

After painting and some more hot glue gun work, the thing was complete!

too lazy to get a non-f/1.8 shot of this

As for how the rest of the cosplay/cosplay group turned out, here's a photo taken by Photography by Coolpplse near our Merchandising booth!

celestial brush gods!

More photos later as they get processed.

entry.title: Sakura-Con 2011 Cosplay Photos: Eeveelutions!
entry.content:
eevee-lution cosplay!

Finally received some of our edited photos from the Eeveelution cosplay that we the merchandising staff did for Sakura-Con 2011! They are all located on the photographer's site here. There are also some group shots that a friend Rachel took on her Flickr stream, starting here.

rawr! (source)

A couple weeks back we finally decided on the theme for our group cosplay for Sakura-Con 2012.  It is...Okami!  We have representatives for all of the Celestial Brush Gods.  I am going to be Moegami, the Phoenix, and it's likely I'm going to be wearing a kimono-like thing yet again.

but it's gonna be all about the skirt next year!

entry.title: Sakura-Con 2011
entry.content:
Edit 11/29: Links to photo galleries can be found in this post!

This is a video Timmy found on Youtube by FastMatt which is essentially the only proof (1:27) that I have of cosplaying at this year's Con. (Actually, there are a couple pictures, but I'm kind of dissatisfied with them, and didn't really have a chance to take pictures of myself...) I did Glaceon and -- oh gosh, I just realized I left my costume at the Convention Center...

....

...well, it wasn't that hard to make. >____>;; It was basically a light blue kimono and some darker portions made with darker blue, all in this sort of quilt fabric that I found at JoAnn's. (Quilt fabric is always in much more versatile colors...) Since I've made gi/kimono-style clothings at least twice before for Con purposes I pretty much just haphazardly threw it together, yet I feel that it's my most successful cosplay yet. Probably because I was with all the other Eevees, and I think we made up a pretty impressive gijinka group. :3

this is kind of an unflattering picture of me, but a good one of everyone else :D

We had more pro pictures taken by Rachel, an apparently amazing artist and cosplayer from San Francisco who does photography as a hobby. She's uber busy though, so it will probably take a couple months for us to actually get the pictures that she took of us. (Apparently she's putting off photo processing until early June! Just enough time to forget about them and then be happy to see them later. :D) We scrambled over the stone features of the Washington State Convention Center and afterwards shivered in turns as we waited for Eric to finish taking individual shots of all of us.

this is a pic that rachel took of some other of merch staff cosplaying blazblue at last year's con
...for the sake of having a picture here

I was busier at this Con than any other year before, mostly because of commitments as staff, and a lesser willingness to get up early and take advantage of wandering Con in the morning. FFXIII and Vocaloid cosplays seemed to be especially popular, or at least, that's what I remember the most, aside from the usual smattering of Akatsuki cloaks, and an interesting blend of different video games, including Minecraft, haha. Also, tons of Hetalia.

My favorite thing to do at Con is usually take pictures, but this year I found I wasn't quite so interested in wandering and asking cosplayers for their pictures...maybe because I've become too jaded, or maybe because I'm just tired of the process itself. For me the joy of Con now comes mostly just from submerging myself in the atmosphere of it -- the excited fanpeoples, the cosplayers who have worked so hard, the shy people who come out all smooth and soft-spoken from their quiet shells from all corners of Seattle and beyond.

It used to be that I would also go for all the stuff you could buy, but I guess I've grown out of that too -- just -- can't think of anything to buy. That being said, I never used to enjoy Artist Alley, but I think I've finally decided that it's another one of my favorite parts of Con -- being there has such a clean, nice, inspiring feeling, unlike being in the general dealer's room. I bought a beautiful print from Zilva and a poster for Andou from Han Tseng, from Directions of Destiny (which I started reading soooo long ago! Guess it's time to check up on it again). I actually grabbed the poster on Sunday; I went back home for Easter celebrations and then rushed from the terminal to fifth floor, where I located Han Tseng's booth, already 90% taken down...luckily he was nice enough to pull out a poster for me despite.

Also this year at Con, I had my picture taken by a DSi for the first time. I wonder what I would have thought of such a thing back when I started attending in 2006...that handhelds and cellphones have become common cameras is just crazy.

So, in summary: Con was great! Can't wait for the next one. :D
